name: transport, freight, aircraft, belly-freight, short haul | transport, freight, aircraft, short haul | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20991/documentation

The dataset represents the transport of one tonne of freight over a distance of between 800 km and 1500 km in a belly-freight aircraft (an aircraft carrying both passengers and freight). The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle including the production of the aircraft, the transportation of goods, and the construction and operation of the airport. The scope of this dataset is the operation of the aircraft, which has inputs of aircraft and airport facilities (i.e. aircraft production and the construction and operation of the airport are contained in linked datasets).;Fuel consumption and the main emissions (SOx, NOx, NMHC, PM and CO) are calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016, based on OAG (2016) data. Flight distances are calculated as the Great Circle Distance (GCD) using coordinates of the destination airports and corrected using a distance dependent factor (74 km (40 nautical miles) for distances below 926 km and 139 km (75 nautical miles) for distances above). For the 0.044% of the flights for which no coordinates for one of the destinations was available,  a flight distance of 1000 km was assumed. Fuel consumption and emissions are based on EMEP/EEA 2016. Linear regression fits were used to approximate fuel consumption and SOx-emissions of all the plane types. For the other emissions, a polynomial of the 3rd degree was used as a fit function. R2 values for fuel consumption and SOx of all plane types are > 0.999. Also for the other emissions, the R2 values are > 0.99 for almost all plane types. Flights are classified according to distance (very short haul < 800 km, short haul between 800 and 1500 km, medium haul between 1500 and 4000 km and long haul > 4000 km). Weighted averages are calculated for each distance class (and for all distances) using the share of each flight to the total transport performance. Passenger transport performance (total pkm) is calculated using the distance of each flight, the typical number of seats for the specific plane type (from ecotransit) used for this flight and an occupancy of 80%. Belly-freight performance is calculated using the distance and the average mass of transported goods per flight (from OAG 2016). Allocation between passenger and freight transport is done  by mass for each flight before averaging, with an assumed passenger mass of 105 kg (including luggage) (EASA 2009). ;CO2, water vapour and heavy metal emissions are calculated from the fuel consumption and from emission factors derived from fuel composition (Spielmann et al. 2007). Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7,315m (FL240). A typical climb/descent procedure for an Airbus A320 is used for the calculation (Source: eurocontrol).;;Certain emissions (formaldehyde, nitrous oxide, methane, ethylene oxide and hydrogen chloride) have been removed in the updated inventory because no reliable source could be found to model them. Furthermore, benzene and butadiene are no longer inventoried separately but included in the exchange "NMVOC", because accounting for them individually is deemed too inaccurate.;Airport facilities have not been updated are representative of a medium-sized international airport (Zurich). Airport demand per tonne freight transported is calculated using a value of 0.4 million tonnes transported per year (based on Zurich airport (2016), and assumes two airports per delivery and a 100 year life of the airport. Aircraft production is global in scope and described in the individual datasets. Aircraft demand per tonne.km is calculated from the lifetime kms and freight loads of over 40 different aircraft, with the aircraft types weighted according to their tonne kms in 2016 (OAG, 2016). Freight load is calculated from the passenger load (maximum number of seats in the different aircraft types and an assumed occupancy factor of 80%) and that passengers account for 86% of the total load (calculated weighted average from OAG data). Aircraft maintenance is not included, although de-icing of aircraft is included in the airport operations.;References:;Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen;EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016;;eurocontrol Aircraft Performance Database, https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/default.aspx?GroupFilter=4, accessed April 2018.                        EASA (2009) Survey on the standard weights of passengers and baggage: Final Report. European Aviation Safety Agency;OAG (2016) OAG Analytics. OAG

The scope of this dataset is the operation of the aircraft, with the production of the aircraft and airport facilities as linked inputs. The transportation service starts with demand for construction of the aircraft and the consumption of fuel (and associated emissions). 

The dataset ends with the service of transporting 1 tonne of freight over a distance of 1 km. The dataset includes the operation of an average flight and links to the production of one average short-haul aircraft (designed to carry both passengers and belly-freight), and the construction and operation of one airport. The dataset includes the consumption of fuel, airborne gaseous emissions, particulate emissions and heavy metal emissions. Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7,315m (FL240). 

Allocation between passengers and freight using actual freight mass and 105 kg per passenger (including luggage) (EASA 2009).
category: H:Transportation and storage/51:Air transport/511:Passenger air transport/5110:Passenger air transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Aircraft and flight data is for all scheduled flights in 2016. Data from one Swiss airport is employed as an estimate for the infrastructure requirement.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data is representative of the global aircraft fleet operating in 2016 (considering age distribution of global fleet).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The carbon dioxide, water vapour and heavy metal emissions are calculated from fuel consumption and the emission factors derived from fuel consumption in Spielmann et al. (2007).                                        Typical climb/descent procedure of an Airbus A320 is used to allocate emission sub-categories (non-urban air or high stacks versus lower stratosphere and upper troposphere) for all airplane types.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Calculation of fuel consumption and emissions performed for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Global flight data; literature data.

flow.name: transport, freight, aircraft, short haul
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/51:Air transport/511:Passenger air transport/5110:Passenger air transport

exchanges.description: Aircraft demand per tonne.km applying a weighted average of lifetime kms and average freight load (from Cox et al, 2018) over 40 different aircraft. Average freight load calculated from estimated passenger weight (average number of seats and an assumed passenger load of 80%) and assuming that passenger weight accounts for 86% of the total weight. Aircraft weighting according to freight transported in 2016 (OAG, 2016).

flow.name: aircraft, belly freight, short haul
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/30:Manufacture of other transport equipment/303:Manufacture of air and spacecraft and related machinery/3030:Manufacture of air and spacecraft and related machinery

defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/30:Manufacture of other transport equipment/303:Manufacture of air and spacecraft and related machinery/3030:Manufacture of air and spacecraft and related machinery

exchanges.description:
Fuel consumption is based on EMEP/EEA (2016), with fuel consumption calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Linear regression fits are used to approximate fuel consumption of all the plane types. The R2 value for fuel consumption of all plane types is > 0.999. 
References:                                                                    EMEP/EEA (2016) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016: 1.A.3.a Aviation. European Environmental Agency

flow.name: kerosene
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/19:Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products/192:Manufacture of refined petroleum products/1920:Manufacture of refined petroleum products

defaultProvider.name: market for kerosene | kerosene | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/19:Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products/192:Manufacture of refined petroleum products/1920:Manufacture of refined petroleum products

exchanges.description:
Heavy metal emissions are calculated from the fuel consumption and emission factors in Spielmann et al (2007) derived from fuel composition*. Fuel consumption is based on EMEP/EEA/Corinair 2016, and with fuel consumption calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Linear regression fit is used to approximate fuel consumption of all the plane types. R2 values for fuel consumption of all plane types are > 0.999. Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7315m (FL240). A typical climb / descent procedure for an A 320 is used for the calculation (source: eurocontrol). 
References: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen                                                                                                                 eurocontrol Aircraft Performance Database, https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/default.aspx?GroupFilter=4, accessed April 2018.                                                                            EMEP/EEA/Corinair (2016) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016: 1.A.3.a Aviation. European Environmental Agency
*Comment in ecoinvent v2 dataset (Spielmann et al., 2007): In order to complete the list is employed heavy metal emission indices for diesel fuels, assuming that the raw fuel and production processes of kerosene fuels are similar to those of diesel.

flow.name: Cadmium II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/lower stratosphere + upper troposphere

exchanges.description:
Water vapour emissions are calculated from the fuel consumption and emission factors in Spielmann et al (2007)*. Fuel consumption is based on EMEP/EEA/Corinair 2016, and with fuel consumption calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Linear regression fit is used to approximate fuel consumption of all the plane types. R2 values for fuel consumption of all plane types are > 0.999. Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7315m (FL240). A typical climb / descent procedure for an A 320 is used for the calculation (source: eurocontrol). 
References: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen; eurocontrol Aircraft Performance Database, https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/default.aspx?GroupFilter=4, accessed April 2018.                                                                                            Comment in ecoinvent v2 dataset (Spielmann et al., 2007): Literature value derived from Lufthansa (2001) and from Andreas DÃ¶pelheuer (2001). Further references: Lufthansa (2001) Balance: Das wichtigste zu Umwelt und Nachhaltigkeit bei Lufthansa. Ausgabe 2000/1. Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Frankfurt a.M.                                                                          EMEP/EEA/Corinair (2016) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016: 1.A.3.a Aviation. European Environmental Agency

Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Frankfurt a.M.                                                              EMEP/EEA/Corinair (2016) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016: 1.A.3.a Aviation. European Environmental Agency

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/lower stratosphere + upper troposphere

exchanges.description:
CO2 emissions are calculated from the fuel consumption and emission factors in Spielmann et al (2007) derived from fuel composition*. Fuel consumption is based on EMEP/EEA/Corinair 2016, and with fuel consumption calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Linear regression fit is used to approximate fuel consumption of all the plane types. R2 values for fuel consumption of all plane types are > 0.999. Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7315m (FL240). A typical climb / descent procedure for an A 320 is used for the calculation (source: eurocontrol). 
References: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen                                                                                                                 eurocontrol Aircraft Performance Database, https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/default.aspx?GroupFilter=4, accessed April 2018.                                                                            EMEP/EEA/Corinair (2016) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016: 1.A.3.a Aviation. European Environmental Agency
*Comment in ecoinvent v2 dataset (Spielmann et al., 2007): Literature value. The combustion of kerosene in aircraft engines is directly coupled with the amount of carbon dioxide and water produced. Due to its nearly constant carbon to hydrogen ratio (a good approximation for the average sum formula is C12H23) the combustion of one kilogram kerosene results in about 3150 g carbon dioxide (CO2).

defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/19:Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products/192:Manufacture of refined petroleum products/1920:Manufacture of refined petroleum products

exchanges.description:
Fuel consumption and emissions are based on EMEP/EEA (2016), with fuel consumption and main emissions (SOx, NOx, NMHC, PM and CO) calculated for 99.5% of all scheduled flights in 2016. Linear regression fits are used to approximate fuel consumption and SOx emissions of all the plane types. For the other emissions, a polynomial of the 3rd degree is used as a fit function. R2 values for fuel consumption and SOx of all plane types are > 0.999. Also for the other emissions, the R2 values are > 0.99 for almost all plane types. Shares of emissions to the lower and upper part of the atmosphere are taken from the shares of the distances covered in the flight phases below and above 7315m (FL240). A typical climb / descent procedure for an A 320 is used for the calculation (source: eurocontrol). 
References: 
EMEP/EEA (2016) EMEP/EEEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2016. European Environmental Agency.
eurocontrol Aircraft Performance Database, https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/default.aspx?GroupFilter=4, accessed April 2018.

flow.name: Sulfur dioxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/lower stratosphere + upper troposphere

exchanges.description:
Infrastructure demand for passenger and freight transport allocated based on Zurich Airport revenue (CHF 427,918,000  and CHF 7,675,000 for passengers and freight respectively (Zurich Airport, 2016)), as that is the airport on which the dataset of airport construction, operation and maintenance is based. Infrastructure demand per tonne of freight transported based on this allocation (1.8% of airport for freight transport) and total freight movements (434 thousand tonnes (Zurich Airport, 2016)) at Zurich Airport. Assumes two airports per item of freight transported and a 100 year airport lifetime (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                             References: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen                                                                                                                                Zurich Airport (2016) Annual Report of Flughafen Zurich AG, Zurich, Switzerland.
EcoSpold01Location=RER
